title: Fine-tuning: The Number ONE Argument for God!
description:
Is our universe an incredible accident‚Äîor is there something more behind its design?
The odds of our universe being just right for life are astronomically small. Yet here we are. How did this happen? In this video, we explore the fascinating concept of fine-tuning‚Äîthe idea that the laws and constants of nature are precisely calibrated to allow life to exist.

We‚Äôll examine the leading explanations:
- Pure luck: Maybe we just won the ultimate cosmic lottery.
- The anthropic principle: Of course we observe a life-permitting universe‚Äîotherwise, we wouldn‚Äôt be here to notice.
- The multiverse: With countless universes, at least one was bound to be life-friendly.
- A fine-tuner: Could the precision of our universe point to a Creator?

By the end of the video, you‚Äôll see why fine-tuning remains one of the most powerful arguments for God‚Äôs existence ‚Äî and why the competing theories fall short. Check it out to learn more about one of the key topics in Christian apologetics.

title: Why Ehrman Thinks Jesus‚Äô Resurrection is a HOAX
description:
Bart Ehrman offers us the following case against the historicity of Jesus' resurrection: In Mark, we may well find the claim that Jesus rose from the dead. However, the story abruptly ends with the women not telling anyone about the risen Christ because they‚Äôre afraid. Nor is there any mention of Jesus appearing to anyone. Mark is the earliest of the four gospels. Thus, the accounts we find in the later three gospels, where the women tell others about the risen Christ, and where the risen Jesus appears to them, don‚Äôt represent what actually happened. Instead, they are theologically motivated embellishments of the story, smuggled in by Matthew, Luke, and John in order to bolster the made-up narrative of a risen Christ. This video is my response to Ehrman's claim.

title: The Reasons for Disbelief are‚Ä¶ PSYCHOLOGICAL?! üò≥
description:
We are often told, especially on the internet, that Christians hold on to their belief out of their need for some magical skydaddy. This is essentially the modern rehashing of Sigmund Freud's claim that "belief in a personal God is psychologically rooted in the notion of an exalted father figure." However, what most atheists don't realize is that Freud, the father of psychoanalysis, didn't just link belief, but also disbelief in God, to psychology. It was Freud's assessment that tipped off Stanford psychologist Paul Vitz to look into the psychological factors that may lead people to atheism. Studying the lives of prominent atheists (such as Friedrich Nietzsche, Sigmund Freud, Ludwig Feuerbach, Josef Stalin, Mao Zedong, Daniel Dennett, Christopher Hitchens, Bertrand Russell, Jean-Paul Sartre, Albert Camus, Arthur Schopenhauer) Vitz concluded that one of the key reasons behind disbelief is related to people's relationship with their father, something he came to call the "Defective Father Hypothesis." This video will look at Vitz's study and show why atheism is rooted by far not only in science and reason, contrary to what internet atheists want you to believe.

title: Science vs Religion?
description: Kristi Burke thinks that science has explained God away and made religion redundant. However, she dishes out a case that is not only self-undermining but also oblivious of key claims made by science and the Christian faith.

title: This is why the Cause in the Kalam is PERSONAL
description: The Kalam Cosmological Argument is arguably one of the most mentioned ones in debates between Christians and atheists. The former frequently mention that the cause which the Kalam deduces must not only be spaceless, timeless, and immaterial, but also personal. While the reason for the first three characteristics can be apprehended fairly easily, it is not immediately clear why the cause talked about in the Kalam should refer to a personal agent also. This lack of clarity seems to play a significant role in the contention put forward by atheists who say that the Kalam may, if granted, get you to some cause behind the universe, but it would get you nowhere close to a personal God. However, upon closer inspection, it turns out that the opposite is the case. This seems to have been conceded by Alex O'Connor aka @CosmicSkeptic  in his conversation with William Lane Craig from @ReasonableFaithOrg. Check out this video to find out why the Kalam cosmological argument, if taken to be sound, does indeed imply a cause that is not only spaceless, timeless, and immaterial, but personal as well.

title: Animal Pain isn‚Äôt THAT BIG of a Problem
description:
Is the amount of suffering animals have to endure compatible with the belief in an all-loving and all-powerful God? Many skeptics would say that it isn‚Äôt. The problem of animal suffering has gained prominence on YouTube especially after @CosmicSkeptic released his Biggest Case Against Christianity a while ago (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KDnnp0sDkI&t=429s). I have already responded just after Alex‚Äôs video came out. This video is a basic and general consideration of the problem of animal suffering. Its purpose is to lay out and critically consider the key assumptions that are typically brought to the table when the problem of animal suffering comes up. Among other things, you will find that evolutionary theory significantly undermines the case of the skeptic and that even Charles Darwin himself thought that, in the animal kingdom, the experience of pleasure and happiness outweighs the experience of pain. Check out this video to learn more about a topic that features prominently in apologetics and debates between atheists and Christians.

title: A Personal God from the Kalam
description: Here's an important note: When I say "... since [the laws of nature] were as inexistent BEFORE the beginning of the universe as the universe itself, to which they apply, was inexistent" this wording isn't quite accurate for the following reason: Time only came to exist with the beginning of the universe, and so with the universe not existing, there is no "before" because there is no time in the first place. What would be more accurate to say is that the laws of nature are inexistent WITHOUT the universe and its beginning. Though I'm fully aware of that,  I chose the "before"-wording since a 1-min short only gives you a limited amount of time to make a point. By default, most people think that there is a "before" the beginning of the universe, though, again, this notion is not coherent. I chose to go with that since I would have had to explain why "without the universe" is a more accurate way of talking (and again, 60 seconds aren't quite enough to mention all of this). Thus, my explanatory note here. Also, I will have a longer video come out on the topic of the personality of the cause which the Kalam cosmological argument deduces, and there, I will mention the very issue described here.

title: Is God Hiding from Alex O'Connor?
description:
Why does God not reveal himself to skeptics and atheists who are genuinely open to a relationship with him but simply don‚Äôt find the evidence for his existence convincing? That's the question Alex O'Connor (aka @CosmicSkeptic), Justin Brierley (@PremierUnbelievable) and I discussed in person at Wycliffe Hall in Oxford on July 11, 2022). The issue is known in philosophy as the problem of divine hiddenness and it has been phrased as a formal argument against God by JL Schellenberg in 1992. In its basic form, it looks as follows:

P1: If God exists, there are no nonresistant nonbelievers.
P2: There are nonresistant nonbelievers.
C: Therefore, God does not exist.

By resistant non-belief, Schellenberg describes the attitude of those atheists, agnostics, or skeptics who are not opposed to the notion of entering into a personal relationship with God. However, they simply don't find themselves believing in him. Resistant non-belief, on the other hand, describes the attitude of those who would refuse to enter into a relationship with God even if they believed that he exists.

Alex O'Connor describes himself as a non-resistant non-believer and has said that he would happily worship God if he believed that he existed. For him, the problem of divine hiddenness is, therefore, not just another philosophical argument to be intellectually assessed. Instead, it's a matter that is directly relevant to his personal life. That's why our conversation was not so much a technical back and forth over the issue at hand as much as it was a reflection on it in light of Alex's experience. I hope you enjoy it!

description:
Are the Gospels reliable? There are three lines of evidence that suggest that what we find in Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John goes back to eyewitness testimony of people who actually knew Jesus. This video will show you why there are plenty of good reasons to trust the gospel accounts. The reliability of the New Testament Scriptures is a key topic in Christian apologetics and Biblical studies. What you will learn here is that archaeology, the gospels' corroboration by outside sources, and their accurate description of the geography of first-century Palestine make for a strong cumulative case for the historicity of the four gospel accounts.

title: Genetically Modified Skeptic‚Äôs WILD View on Evil
description:
The ‚Äúpink t-shirt me‚Äù represents Genetically Modified Skeptic and the ‚Äúblue t-shirt me‚Äù is, well, me. Just a little disclaimer in order for you to understand the story that‚Äôs happening in the background.

Not too long ago, Drew aka @GeneticallyModifiedSkeptic put out a response to Greg Koukl from @STRvideos. As part of that response, Drew discussed the problem of evil. Most atheists claim that the problem of evil is internal to Christianity only, and Drew is no exception as he repeatedly asserts this point in his video. Now, if you, as an atheist, deny moral realism (the view that good and evil exist objectively), you are 100% justified in locating the problem of evil in Christianity (or in theism, in general). However, an atheist who affirms moral realism (i.e. an atheist who affirms that good and evil are objective) has his own problem of evil to deal with as he or she needs to give an account of how good and evil are to be grounded. In this video, I will point out that Drew presupposes, even for his own self-identity, the existence of objective morality. This means that he is among those atheists who face the problem of accounting for evil (and for good), just like Christians do. In other words, it won‚Äôt do for him to simply regurgitate the ‚Äúevil is an internal critique of Christianity‚Äù slogan that‚Äôs popular among atheists. Yet, it seems that that‚Äôs all he‚Äôs got to offer. And it‚Äôs not even half of it, because Drew goes on to blatantly contradict himself by both affirming and denying the existence of objective moral facts. Enjoy!

Link to Drew‚Äôs original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fsw-lSp3rq8&t=1224s
The three relevant quotes about evil being a problem that‚Äôs internal to Christianity appear at 25.11, 26.46, and 29.36. They are part of the greater section in which Drew responds to Greg Koukl‚Äôs explanations about the moral argument and the problem of evil (21.45-31.50).

Link to Drew's video about humanism: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQ1TJ7oUMHg&t=735s

Skeptics often raise the following two objections against the gospels and their reliability: First, the authors didn‚Äôt identify themselves, which means that these stories might not actually have been written by Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. title: Why Naturalism CANNOT Explain the Origin of Life
description:
Can a living cell be built by mere chance or the bare necessities of natural law acting on dead matter? How did the genetic code originate? Can naturalistic processes explain the origin of the protein production process in the cell? In this interview, I‚Äôm joined by Rob Stadler (Ph.D. Medical Engineering MIT) who has written about the question of the origin of life in his book ‚ÄúStairway to Life.‚Äù He sheds light on several biochemical phenomena which elude naturalistic explanations and raises the question of whether the methodological naturalism prevalent in the sciences is still justified. The truth is that various aspects of the cell machinery resemble the kind of systems human engineers come up with. Accordingly, the question of whether biochemical structures have been engineered or designed is raised naturally.

Check out Rob‚Äôs work here: https://www.scientificevolution.com/

title: Rationality Rules Does NOT Understand Christianity
description:
Why does God punish people infinitely in hell for the finite amount of sins they committed during their earthly existence? Stephen Woodford aka @rationalityrules recently critiqued hell as he responded to a discussion on the topic of hell between Cameron Bertuzzi from @CapturingChristianity and William Lane Craig from @drcraigvideos. The problem of hell is a serious one, for sure, and one that repeatedly comes up in Christian apologetics and debates between Christians and atheists or skeptics. Unfortunately, however, various misconceptions about what Christian doctrine actually teaches about the afterlife cloud people‚Äôs understanding of hell, and Stephen Woodford is no exception. In this video, I will show why Rationality Rules‚Äô has essentially attacked a straw-manned version of hell that isn‚Äôt taught by Christianity. I hope that this video will help you grasp the basic Christian teaching about heaven and hell as well as help you understand why the notion of God‚Äôs love is perfectly consistent with it.

title: Why it‚Äôs 98% Certain That There‚Äôs NO Tree of Life
description:
Paleontology poses an insurmountable challenge to the theory of evolution. Charles Darwin himself predicted that countless intermediate animal forms must exist within the fossil record, given that organisms gradually evolved from one species into the next. However, what the fossil record actually shows is the exact opposite, namely, that whenever new species appear, they do so suddenly and without evidence of precursory forms in the geological record. The most prominent example is the so-called Cambrian explosion which happened around 530 million years ago, when about 20 animal phyla suddenly showed up on the stage of life out of the clear blue, as it were, but with no intermediate forms from the Precambrian strata. Given that no attempt to reconcile paleontology with evolutionary theory has succeeded, Darwinian evolutionists have come to admit that the fossil record doesn‚Äôt fit with their theory, as we will see at the end of this video. For the same reason, they‚Äôve started to turn their focus towards another field of study in their search for support of evolution: Homology and phylogenetic trees. This episode assesses these efforts and shows why neither homologous structures nor tree of life studies support evolutionary theory.

This series is a partnership between my channel and Discovery Institute, the main think tank on the topic of Intelligent Design and the interface between science and religion.

The word ‚ÄúTrinity‚Äù cannot be found in the New Testament (nor in the Old Testament, for that matter). In this video I will lay out why the teaching of the New Testament implies that God is three persons in one nature and that the notion of God being triune is right there in the text. title: Jordan Peterson to Sam Harris: "I'm PRAYING..."
Hey @ApostateProphet, what about those grapes?
6 Literal Creation Days?
description:
Are the days in the Genesis creation account meant as literal 24-hour days? I believe there are very good reasons to believe that they are NOT primarily because the Old Testament writers frequently use the word ‚Äúday‚Äù (yom in Hebrew) in a generic sense to speak about a period of time, just as we do when we say, for example, that in this day and age, most people have an Instagram account.‚Äù

For example, in Joshua, it says that ‚ÄúIsrael served the Lord all the days of Joshua‚Äù where the word ‚Äúdays‚Äù is clearly not meant to be understood as 24-hour periods. Even in the creation account itself, yom is used in a non-literal fashion when the writer summarizes what God did during the entire creation week by talking about ‚Äú‚Ä¶ the day that the LORD God made the earth and the heavens.‚Äù [Gen. 2:4]

The Bible offers us good reasons to hold that the days in Genesis are not literal 24 hour periods, and I hope this video gives you a good reason to subscribe so that you get my videos in days to come. Check out this video to learn more about a key apologetics issue at the interface between science and faith.

title: 3 Lessons I Learned From LOSING Arguments
description:
What do you do when you go blank in a discussion? What when you lose an argument or don‚Äôt know how to answer a question? If you‚Äôre involved in apologetic, philosophical, or theological conversations with skeptics or atheists, you will probably know what it feels like when things don‚Äôt go as you expected them. I believe that anyone who‚Äôs involved in Christian apologetics and engagement with non-Christians does well to actually think through the ‚Äúloser scenario‚Äù and wrap his head around how to deal with it. In this video, I share from my own experience what these rather uncomfortable moments have taught me and offer a few simple reflections based on the Bible and the teachings of Jesus. No matter whether you‚Äôre a Christian, atheist, or skeptic, I hope this video encourages you for your engagement with ‚Äúthe other.‚Äù Enjoy!

I‚Äôm aware that it may be difficult for some of us to accept such criticism. But the Bible offers us plenty of examples in which God used the most unlikely people outside the community of faith to challenge those who claim to be his servants. Thus, let‚Äôs not too quickly dismiss what non-Christians have to say about us.

title: "Christians IMPOSE Their Belief on Others!" #short
description: Many skeptics don't like that Christians evangelize, and they criticize believers for "forcing their faith down people's throats." Similarly, they feel that advocacy against issues such as abortion or gay marriage is a matter of Christians imposing their belief on an entire society. However, what these critics don't realize is that by virtue of their criticism, they themselves have become guilty of the very thing they accuse Christians of. Enjoy!

title: Stephen: Still CLUELESS About Free Will & Neuroscience
description:
The claim that neuroscience has debunked free will has become fairly widespread. Rationality Rules, one of the most prominent atheist YouTubers, is at the forefront preaching this exact message. He proclaims that ‚Äúscience is telling us loud and clear and unequivocally that while our feelings of free will are real free will itself is an illusion.‚Äù His case is based on what are arguably the two most often-cited studies in neuroscience which presumably showed that determinism is true and free will doesn‚Äôt exist (which means that by watching my video you‚Äôll not only get to see my response to¬†@rationalityrules but you‚Äôll learn about the nuts and bolts that are behind the popular claim that neuroscience has debunked free will). The first one is the work of Benjamin Libet, a pioneering neuroscientist who published a groundbreaking study in the early 1980s. The second one is the work of Chun Siong Soon. This video is part #2 of my response to Stephen‚Äôs case (part #1 is here: https://youtu.be/RYUV5DyQxH4). It continues with the analysis of Stephen‚Äôs treatment of Libet‚Äôs work and looks at his utilization of Soon‚Äôs work, too. One of the most eye-opening lessons you will learn is that neuroscience doesn‚Äôt show that we form our decisions before we become aware of them, contrary to the claim that‚Äôs at the core of Rationality Rules‚Äô argument. But that‚Äôs just the tip of the iceberg‚Ä¶ I hope you will enjoy this video which deals with a key theme in Christian apologetics and in debates between skeptics and Christians.

Stephen's original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j4Oyi1T-HmU&t=375s

For most of my criticism, I follow Albert R. Mele‚Äôs work ‚ÄúFree: Why Science Hasn‚Äôt Disproved Free Will‚Äù (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014).

Study done by Haggard and Magno: Patrick Haggard and Elena Magno, ‚ÄúLocalising awareness of action with transcranial magnetic stimulation,‚Äù Exp Brain Res (1999) 127: 102-107.

A big THANK YOU to my friend Dan Miller who helped me a great deal to think carefully about the issues pertaining to free will and determinism.

title: A Meaningless Universe? The Peterson-Krauss Conversation
description:
Jordan Peterson and Lawrence Krauss recently talked about the beginning of the universe and its meaning. Krauss believes that there is no objective purpose to our existence, adding that ‚Äúwe create our own purpose.‚Äù Peterson, on the other hand, holds that meaning isn‚Äôt something that you create. Instead, it‚Äôs ‚Äúout there‚Äù and it ‚Äúbursts on you,‚Äù particularly in the form of scientific discoveries which reveal the structure upon which the universe is built. Krauss‚Äôs argument against an objective meaning behind the universe comes from his observations as a physicist. He states that while the universe fundamentally operates in ways captured by quantum physics, we render our day-to-day description of the world around us in the terms of classical physics. He takes this to mean that the world around us is not only an illusion but also devoid of any purpose. This conversation really caused me to wrestle personally with the question of meaning. I believe that philosophically speaking, Krauss‚Äôs argument fails. If we‚Äôre just a ‚Äúmomentary accident,‚Äù as he puts it, we cannot also be ‚Äúspecial,‚Äù as he moves on to assert. Christian theism as well as atheist thinkers such as Sartre, Camus, and Russell have argued that without eternity as part of your worldview,  you end up with nihilism and your existence is meaningless. However, in everyday life, people don‚Äôt constantly think about eternal life, and yet they feel that their existence is meaningful. This is why the Peterson-Krauss conversation caused me to wrestle personally with the question of how useful the discussion about meaning actually is. Check out the video about a key topic in Christian apologetics and debates between atheists, skeptics, and Christians. I hope you enjoy it and look forward to hearing your feedback.

title: Basics of Intelligent Design: Messing with Darwin
description:
In the 1970s and 1980s, two American paleontologists came up with a revolutionary attempt to reconcile Darwinian evolution with the fossil record. Stephen Jay Gould and Niles Eldredge called their hypothesis ‚ÄúPunctuated Equilibrium.‚Äù This theory holds that evolution doesn‚Äôt happen slowly, gradually, and continuously, but rather rapidly and in limited periods of time. The key argument with which Gould and Eldredge backed up their unconventional theory is known as allopatric speciation. Punctuated Equilibrium created significant noise in the scientific community as it challenged the key tenets of Darwinism and Neo-Darwinism, and it came to be referred to as ‚Äúevolution by jerks‚Äù and ‚ÄúPunk Eek.‚Äù The hypothesis fails in various respects, however, and even Gould himself, recognizing the significant shortcomings and inconsistencies of Punctuated Equilibrium, later started to reconcile his theorizing again with Neo-Darwinian orthodoxy. This means, that the Cambrian explosion and the lack fo intermediate forms in the fossil record persists as a serious challenge to evolutionary theory. This episode in our series on Intelligent Design and critical thinking about evolution will cover all the basics and relevant aspects you need to know about Punctuated Equilibrium. Punctuated Equilibrium is the last major attempt of Darwinists to reconcile paleontology with evolution and its failure seems to seal the incompatibility of Darwinian theory with the fossil record once and for all. Join me for this episode which lays another important foundation upon which the argument for Intelligent Design will later be built.

0:00 Intro & Recap
2:58 What is Punctuated Equilibrium?
4:51 What led to Punk Eek?
6:18 Allopatric Speciation
8:40 Species Selection
10:32 No Pool Available
11:28 Large Populations Needed
14:25 No Complex Traits
18:12 Punk Eek Retreats
19:47 Back to Square 1

This is the third video of an ongoing series on the Evolution vs. Intelligent Design debate. My aim is to make the basics of Intelligent Design and of critical thinking about evolutionary theory available to the uninitiated viewer. I will unpack, in a step-by-step fashion, why the complex, specified information we find in organisms of the animal kingdom is better explained by the theory of Intelligent Design than by Neo-Darwinism.

The videos in these series are based on the New York Times bestseller ‚ÄúDarwin‚Äôs Doubt: The Explosive Origin of Animal Life and the Case for Intelligent Design‚Äù by Stephen C. Meyer (Revised ed. Edition, San Francisco: HarperOne, 2014). In fact, the videos can be thought of as summaries of the most essential points of Meyer‚Äôs book.

This series is done in partnership with the Discovery Institute, the leading Intelligent Design think tank (https://www.discovery.org/). The Discovery Institute is sometimes accused of advancing Biblical creationism disguised as science. This is an ad hominem attack that does nothing to address the actual arguments that are being put forward by Intelligent Design theorists. Besides, the accusation reveals ignorance of the fact that there is a wide range of atheist and agnostic scientists who consider Intelligent Design a legitimate scientific hypothesis. Nevertheless, one of my videos will talk about how the hypotheses advanced by Intelligent Design and creationism are fundamentally different.

I have not received formal training in evolutionary biology. However, I have spent a great amount of time studying Neo-Darwinism and Intelligent Design over the last three years. I am mentioning this for two reasons: First, this is simply a matter of transparency and intellectual honesty, which are, I believe, key, as we‚Äôre dealing with a controversial topic. Second, I‚Äôm aware that the fact of me not being an evolutionary biologist will be used by critics in the attempt to undermine the credibility of the arguments I offer here. However, the validity of an argument is not affected by the question of who advances it. Therefore, questioning my content because I‚Äôm not an evolutionary biologist (or, a scientist, for that matter) is logically fallacious. In addition, the following may be pointed out: Unless the person who offers such criticism is him or herself an evolutionary biologist, advancing such criticism is at best hypocritical and at worst self-defeating. For if the credibility of my arguments is supposedly questionable due to me not being an evolutionary biologist, why should the critic‚Äôs criticism of my arguments be any more credible, given that he or she isn‚Äôt an evolutionary biologist either?

As always, I'm thankful for feedback!

title: Stephen Has NO CLUE About Neuroscience & Free Will
description:
The claim that neuroscience has debunked free will has become fairly widespread and Rationality Rules, one of the most prominent atheist YouTubers, is at the forefront preaching this exact message. He proclaims that ‚Äúscience is telling us loud and clear and unequivocally that while our feelings of free will are real free will itself is an illusion.‚Äù His case is based on what are arguable the two most often-cited studies in neuroscience which presumably showed that determinism is true and free will doesn‚Äôt exist (which means that by watching my video you‚Äôll not only get to see my response to @rationalityrules but you‚Äôll learn about the nuts and bolts that are behind the popular claim that neuroscience has debunked free will). The first one is the work of Benjamin Libet, a pioneering neuroscientist who published a groundbreaking study in the early 1980s. The second one is the work of Chun Siong Soon. This video is part #1 of my response to Stephen‚Äôs case (part #2 will follow later) and it deals exclusively with Stephen‚Äôs treatment of Libet‚Äôs work. One of the most eye-opening lessons you will learn is that Benjamin Libet himself never thought of his work as providing evidence for determinism and against free will. Quite the opposite, actually. This means that Rationality Rules has essentially hijacked and abused Libet‚Äôs work for a case that Libet himself would never have supported. But that‚Äôs just the tip of the iceberg‚Ä¶ I hope you will enjoy this video which deals with a key theme in Christian apologetics and in debates between skeptics and Christians.

Stephen's original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j4Oyi1T-HmU&t=375s

For most of my criticism, I follow Albert R. Mele‚Äôs work ‚ÄúFree: Why Science Hasn‚Äôt Disproved Free Will‚Äù (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014).

A big THANK YOU to my friend Dan Miller who helped me a great deal to think carefully about the issues pertaining to free will and determinism.

title: The Trinity in the Old Testament
description:
God is three in one ‚Äî Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. This is one of the most fundamental doctrines of the Christian faith. However, how do you derive the Trinity from the Bible? In particular, can the Trinity be found in the Old Testament or is it only present in the New Testament? This video will look at a range of different OT passages, starting from Genesis, to the Psalms, Ezekiel, and Isaiah, and show you how they point to God being triune. The truth is that the Old Testament is full of passages that cannot be reconciled with unitarianism (the view that God is one in nature and one in person), but they make perfect sense against the backdrop of Trinitarianism, which tells us that God is one in nature and three in persons. Enjoy!

There's a mistake regarding a verse reference: At 2:12, the verse is from Ez. 36:27, not from Ez. 36:37.

title: My Cumulative Case Against Cosmic Skeptic
description:
Here's to a deep dive into Alex O'Connor's worldview! Over the past months, I've put out several responses that are either directly or indirectly related to his moral philosophy. In this video, I'm combining all of my counter-arguments into one cumulative case against @CosmicSkeptic. I will show how his case against free will essentially eradicates morality as he himself defines it, thus depriving all of his moral reasoning of a proper ontological foundation. We will also see how his meta-ethical framework doesn't even qualify as an ethical theory, properly speaking. Even if it did, however, it would still have to be rejected for its absurdity as it condones rape as the moral option in a wide variety of cases. In addition, Alex's biggest case against Christianity based on animal suffering directly contradicts his quasi-utilitarian ethical theory which puts the pursuit of pleasure at its center. These are, I suggest, some of the biggest inconsistencies within Alex's worldview. Even so, as I point out in the end, I believe we have a lot to learn from Cosmic Skeptic, not simply because he is a sharp thinker, but much more because he takes the question of how we ought to live very seriously on a personal level. Enjoy!

title: Who Are You? #shorts
description:
Hey, thanks for watching! My #shorts aim to tackle popular issues in Christian apologetics and theology with simplicity and brevity. I'm passionate to bring atheists, skeptics, and theists together to debate and talk about the question of God and ultimate reality. Good philosophical arguments matter, but people matter even more.

Some people believe that you as a human being are nothing but matter, 100% physical and that the idea of an immaterial soul is superstition.

If that‚Äôs true, it has some rather weird implications: It means that after cutting your hair you‚Äôre not identical anymore to who you were before you cut your hair. You see, if who you are is defined exclusively in terms of matter it means that as your physical make-up changes, the ‚Äúyou‚Äù changes.

Also, consider that your body renews all its cells every 7-10 years. If you‚Äôre just matter, this means that you become a different person every decade. In fact, our physicality constantly changes, we lose around 30,000 skin cells every minute which means that you are now not the person anymore who clicked on this video 30 seconds ago.

Now, clearly, this is absurd. But while it‚Äôs absurd it‚Äôs nevertheless the consistent outworking of saying that we‚Äôre nothing but matter.

title: Basics of Intelligent Design: Still NO Fossils!!?
description:
Are you familiar with the basics of evolutionary theory? Then you might know that the fossil record actually puts evolution in real trouble. You might also know that various theories have been put forward by Darwin‚Äôs advocates in an attempt to fix that problem. In this video, I‚Äôm going to show you why these attempts not only fail but even amplify the Darwinian dilemma. This is my second video in my ongoing series on Intelligent Design. In the previous episode, I talked about how Darwin was painstakingly aware of the fact that his theory was diametrically opposed to the fossil record which, then as now, shows that new animal forms show up SUDDENLY and without any intermediate forms preceding them. Darwin was hoping that as paleontology would progress, later discoveries would produce those forms and vindicate his theory. Yet, the exact opposite happened: Paleontologists have found EVEN MORE evidence of new animal forms suddenly appearing for the first time out of the blue as it were, in the era called ‚Äúthe Cambrian,‚Äù without any precursory forms in the preceding geological era. This phenomenon is called ‚Äúthe Cambrian explosion‚Äù and it completely defies the Darwinian idea of gradual change over time. Check out my first video to get a better idea of the details. In this video, I‚Äôm gonna walk you through three of the most important theories (artifact hypothesis, Ediacaran fossils etc.) that have been proposed in the attempt to plug the hole, and what you‚Äôll get to see at the end is that these theories not only don‚Äôt close that gap but actually widen it significantly.

0:00 Intro & Recap
1:44 The Artifact Hypothesis
2:46 Too Soft & Too Small?
4:18 The Ediacaran Fauna
6:18 Evaluating the Ediacaran Fauna
9:29 80% Unexplained
12:35 An Even Bigger Problem!
14:07 Conclusion

This is the second video of an ongoing series on the Evolution vs. Intelligent Design debate. My aim is to make the basics of Intelligent Design and of critical thinking about evolutionary theory available to the uninitiated viewer. I will unpack, in a step-by-step fashion, why the complex, specified information we find in organisms of the animal kingdom is better explained by the theory of Intelligent Design than by Neo-Darwinism.

The videos in these series are based on the New York Times bestseller ‚ÄúDarwin‚Äôs Doubt: The Explosive Origin of Animal Life and the Case for Intelligent Design‚Äù by Stephen C. Meyer (Revised ed. Edition, San Francisco: HarperOne, 2014). In fact, the videos can be thought of as summaries of the most essential points of Meyer‚Äôs book.

This series is done in partnership with the Discovery Institute, the leading Intelligent Design think tank (https://www.discovery.org/).

description: Hey, thanks for watching! My #shorts aim to tackle popular issues in Christian apologetics and theology with simplicity and brevity. title: No, Consciousness is NOT Emergent from Matter!
description: Materialists and atheists like to talk about the supposedly ‚Äúemergent properties‚Äù of consciousness. What they mean is that the mind is fully reducible to matter, and that there is, therefore, nothing immaterial to a human being, and certainly no soul either. Materialist often cite neuroscience and the newest neuroscientific findings in support of their position. Their view can be described as physicalism and it opposes dualism which holds that human are both physical and non-physical, that we have a body and what has traditionally been called a soul. The philosophy of mind deals with the question of the origin and nature of consciousness, a mystery that has haunted philosophers since the time of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle. I did a one-hour interview with philosopher of mind JP Moreland. This video is an excerpt and it deals with the question of whether emergent properties exist and what they are. Enjoy!

title: The Bible and Women #shorts
description:
Hey, thanks for watching! My #shorts aim to tackle popular issues in Christian apologetics and theology with simplicity and brevity. I'm passionate to bring atheists, skeptics, and theists together to debate and talk about the question of God and ultimate reality. Good philosophical arguments matter, but people matter even more.

This video is about the often-heard claim that the creation account in Genesis supposedly degrades women for two particular reasons. First, because it says that Eve was made from a piece or a rib taken from Adam and second because Eve is described as Adam‚Äôs helper. Here‚Äôs my response:

First, just because Eve is taken from Adam does not mean that she is inferior to him. By the same logic, it would we would have to conclude that Adam is inferior to dirt because it says that God formed HIM from the dust of the ground. But clearly just because the Bible says that something is made from something else, it doesn‚Äôt follow that the ‚Äúraw material‚Äù is more valuable than the final product, and this applies as much to dirt and Adam as it does to Adam and Eve.

Similarly, just because Eve is described as Adam‚Äôs helper it doesn‚Äôt follow that she is inferior to him, or simply his servant. In fact, the Hebrew word for ‚Äòhelper‚Äô applied to Eve is applied to God himself when the Bible describes him as the helper of his people. But clearly, it doesn‚Äôt intend to tell us that God the helper is inferior to the people he helps. That would be absurd.

I hope this clears things up. Thank you for watching! Check out my channel for more.

title: Does the Trinity Make Sense?
description:
What does it mean to say that God is three in one? The Trinity is one of the most mind-boggling Christian doctrines, and yet, it is also among its most fundamental ones. This video will introduce the basics every Christian needs to know when it comes to the Trinity. We will look at the difference between the concept of nature and the concept of personhood. This is crucial because to say that God is triune is to say that he is three ‚Äúin persons" but one in nature. In contrast, it would be a self-contradiction to say that God is three persons and one person or three gods and yet one god at one and the same time. Three persons, one nature, that‚Äôs the bare basics to be grasped when it comes to the Trinity and it‚Äôs an absolutely fundamental concept to be understood by anyone who is into theology, Christian apologetics and philosophy. If you want to defend your faith against skeptics or atheists, you better know who the God is you actually believe in. He is one in nature, but three in persons ‚Äî Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. This video will not yet look into Scriptural support for the Trinity. In two upcoming videos, however, I will show you how a Trinitarian view of God clearly emerges from the Old Testament and the New Testament. These episodes will show that unitarianism (the view that God is one in nature and one in person) cannot be reconciled with the Bible. But we‚Äôre getting ahead of ourselves‚Ä¶ Check out this video and get a basic understanding of how to think about the triune God who revealed himself in Jesus Christ.

title: Basics of Intelligent Design: Darwin‚Äôs Nightmare
description:
When Charles Darwin published ‚ÄúOn the Origin of Species‚Äù in 1859, he was painstakingly aware of the fact that the fossil record diametrically opposed his theory. Ever since Darwin‚Äôs time, paleontologists have put their finger on the so-called Cambrian explosion. The term describes the fact that within one single geological era called the Cambrian era, a wide variety of fossilized animal forms shows up suddenly and without any evidence of intermediate forms preceding them in Precambrian strata. This state of affairs is hard to reconcile with Darwin‚Äôs idea that species evolved slowly and gradually over long periods of time. Darwin himself acknowledged this problem and admitted that if we assume the theory of evolution to be true, we should find an interminable number of intermediate forms in the fossil record. However, at Darwin‚Äôs time, those countless transitional forms were nowhere to be found. The leading figures of paleontology didn‚Äôt hold back with their criticism of Darwin, who, in turn, described their objections as potentially fatal to the entire theory of evolution. Yet, instead of dealing with the paleontological evidence as it presented itself to him, Darwin explained away the absence of paleontological evidence for evolution by asserting that future discoveries by paleontologists would eventually unearth those countless intermediate forms that his theory needed in order to be vindicated. Have his hopes come true? No, they haven‚Äôt. In fact, as the science of paleontology has, like any other scientific discipline during the 20th century, made huge leaps forward, the evidence that has emerged has put the theory of evolution into even greater trouble. Find out why in this very first episode of my new series on the basics of Intelligent Design.

0:00 Intro
0:52 Darwin's Theory
2:16 A Troubling Conundrum
4:42 A Milestone Discovery
5:09 Phyla and Fossils
6:38 The Blink of an Eye
7:28 Amazing Trilobite
8:22 Stubborn Paleontology
9:05 Darwin's Problem Amplified
11:23 Wrapping Up & Looking Ahead

This is the first video of an ongoing series on the Evolution vs. Intelligent Design debate. My aim is to make the basics of Intelligent Design and of critical thinking about evolutionary theory available to the uninitiated viewer. I will unpack, in a step-by-step fashion, why the complex, specified information we find in organisms of the animal kingdom is better explained by the theory of Intelligent Design than by Neo-Darwinism.

The videos in these series are based on the New York Times bestseller ‚ÄúDarwin‚Äôs Doubt: The Explosive Origin of Animal Life and the Case for Intelligent Design‚Äù by Stephen C. Meyer (Revised ed. Edition, San Francisco: HarperOne, 2014). In fact, the videos can be thought of as summaries of the most essential points of Meyer‚Äôs book. This video in particular relates to the content of chapters 1-2.

This series is done in partnership with the Discovery Institute, the leading Intelligent Design think tank (https://www.discovery.org/). The Discovery Institute is sometimes accused of advancing Biblical creationism disguised as science. This is an ad hominem attack that does nothing to address the actual arguments that are being put forward by Intelligent Design theorists. Besides, the accusation reveals ignorance of the fact that there is a wide range of atheist and agnostic scientists who consider Intelligent Design a legitimate scientific hypothesis. Nevertheless, one of my videos will talk about how the hypotheses advanced by Intelligent Design and creationism are fundamentally different.

I have not received formal training in evolutionary biology. However, I have spent a great amount of time studying Neo-Darwinism and Intelligent Design over the last three years. I am mentioning this for two reasons: First, this is simply a matter of transparency and intellectual honesty, which are, I believe, key, as we‚Äôre dealing with a controversial topic. Second, I‚Äôm aware that the fact of me not being an evolutionary biologist will be used by critics in the attempt to undermine the credibility of the arguments I offer here. However, the validity of an argument is not affected by the question of who advances it. Therefore, questioning my content because I‚Äôm not an evolutionary biologist (or, a scientist, for that matter) is logically fallacious. In addition, the following may be pointed out: Unless the person who offers such criticism is him or herself an evolutionary biologist, advancing such criticism is at best hypocritical and at worst self-defeating. For if the credibility of my arguments is supposedly questionable due to me not being an evolutionary biologist, why should the critic‚Äôs criticism of my arguments be any more credible, given that he or she isn‚Äôt an evolutionary biologist either?

As always, I'm thankful for feedback!

title: Cosmic Skeptic‚Äôs Ethics is Utterly ABSURD!
description:
Alex O‚ÄôConnor loves to talk about ethics, as he himself says. However, the ethical theory he has built sanctifies as good that which we all know to be outright evil, as I point out in this video. The first part offers a summary of  @CosmicSkeptic ‚Äôs ethics and lays out the key foundations on which it stands. The second part takes a critical look at Alex‚Äôs ethics and reveals its absurdity. Alex's primary inspiration for his ethics is taken from the utilitarian tradition, which focuses on pleasure. In fact, many atheists and skeptics follow the same path in trying to account for our moral awareness. And, similar to Alex, they may refer to science in trying to back up their position. However, while Alex certainly talks about science in making his argument from pleasure, he doesn‚Äôt actually offer scientific evidence for it. Given that various forms of utilitarianism are popular among atheists, this video will be helpful for anyone who is involved in apologetic discussions and debates with them. My video does not offer an actual theory of Biblical ethics, nor does it explain how Christianity or the existence of God can ground moral values. The singular aim of this video is to point out that the ethical framework Cosmic Skeptic has built is worthless. Enjoy!
 
DISCLAIMERS:
1) There is a bit of background noise in the first 5 minutes - I‚Äôm sorry!

2) Alex speaks about ethics in a lot of different videos and contexts. Some of those videos are quite old and no longer represent his views, as he himself clarifies in more recent videos. As far as I‚Äôm aware, there are two key videos in which Alex lays out his case for objective (or quasi-objective) ethics. One is a conversation with  @Rationality Rules, found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrYLvaXCokg&t=3357s. In his conversation with Stephen Woodford, Alex mainly reiterates the case he presented to a group of humanists which is found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htdDaHAhR-s&t=3888s. It‚Äôs in this presentation that Alex offers his case for objective ethics most concisely and clearly, as far as I‚Äôm concerned at least. He also references this presentation in subsequent and quite recent videos where he clarifies his stance on ethics. This is why all citations and quotations in my video are taken from there. The quality of that video is, however, quite bad, which is why I didn‚Äôt include the original footage when quoting Alex.

3) Many people seem to be confused about Alex‚Äôs ethics and this seems to stem from either of two facts (or a mixture of both): First, they hold on to their ideas taken from Alex‚Äôs older videos in which he may have questioned the existence of morality. Second, they assume that, as an atheist, Alex fits the atheist stereotype of explicitly denying the existence of a moral realm. I hope (and believe) that my video is an accurate representation as well as a helpful engagement with what Alex actually believes about morality.

title: Do Churches Influence You Emotionally? Yes & No.
description:
If you've ever visited a church service on Sunday, you will know that music and rituals play a rather important role. Drew from @GeneticallyModifiedSkeptic claims that church leaders utilize these tools intentionally, creating an emotionally charged atmosphere that makes people more receptive and impressionable. According to him, Christianity simply isn't intellectually compelling which is why the church must revert to what he calls "emotional priming" in order to convert people and maintain membership. Many skeptics and atheists will probably share his opinion. But they are not alone. In this video, I talk about why Drew is actually spot-on with some of the things he says. While his critique isn't flawless, Drew has managed, I believe, to successfully point out that much of contemporary Christianity has fallen prey to the cultural lie that what you feel is more important than what you think. Some people will even use the Bible and Jesus' teaching to support their heart-over-mind approach to belief in God. In response, I'm trying to offer a theologically more healthy way of considering the mind and the heart, which is a core issue for apologetics, theology, and Christianity's engagement with culture.

title: No, It's ALEX's Problem: He DEBUNKED Atheism!
description:
Is the suffering of wild animals "Christianity's Biggest Problem?" @CosmicSkeptic thinks so. He recently published a video in which he claims that the problem of animal suffering is even bigger than the problem of human suffering and that atheism makes far more sense of it than Christianity ever could. In this video, I am going to show you that Alex‚Äôs case is essentially an emotional appeal that directly contradicts Darwin's theory of evolution. But that's not even half of it. You are going to witness how Alex‚Äôs biggest shot AGAINST Christianity actually turns into Alex‚Äôs most convincing argument FOR it. If you are into Christian apologetics, philosophy, and the debate between atheism and Christian theism, this video is for you! Enjoy!

Alex's original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KDnnp0sDkI&t=897s

---- Clarification (Darwinian Evolution, Intelligent Design & Alex's Case) ----
My personal position on Darwinian evolution is NOT relevant to my case against Alex in which I intentionally decided to accept and assume all of ALEX's presuppositions. I happen to believe that Darwinian evolution is not an accurate theory of how species originated. In contrast, Alex believes that it is.

What IS relevant, however, is the following:  If the theory of evolution is true (and Alex believes that it is), Christianity is, according to Alex's own reasoning, incalculably more plausible than atheism when we consider the natural state animals live in (which is a state of happiness, as evolutionary theory proposes, rather than of torment).

But just to be clear, if we were to assume Intelligent Design (which represents my personal position), my case against Alex would still stand. And that's because animal existence being predominated by happiness is a claim that can be plausibly maintained against the background of ID theory. Of course, a lot more could be said about this topic. However, I chose not to elaborate on it because, again, my response is committed to working within ALEX's assumptions and ALEX's line of reasoning ONLY, and at no point does my case build on MY presuppositions.

So, again: If we want to explain the nature of animal existence in the real world while assuming all the tenets of ALEX's argument, Christianity turns out to be incalculably more plausible than atheism. Alex's atheism has been defeated with Alex's own weapons.

title: My MARTYRED Neighbours & the RISEN Jesus
description:
Would you be willing to die for a cause you really believe in? Up until recently, I used to live in a neighborhood where many people actually WOULD give their lives to their cause, and in this video I‚Äôm gonna show you why looking at their stories and mindset offers compelling raw material to build a case for Christ‚Äôs resurrection.

The resurrection of Jesus is the key event upon which Christianity is based. Arguing for its historicity is therefore of paramount importance in apologetics. From the New Testament and other sources, we know that Peter, Paul, and most of the other apostles were killed because they proclaimed Christ as Lord. The fact that the apostles were willing to lay down their lives for the sake of the gospel makes for a compelling argument that Jesus really did rise from the dead. Of course, all sorts of people are willing to die for their faith, even today, and the most well-known example is probably that of Muslim fundamentalists. However, why the martyrdom of the apostles is an entirely different case is what I will point out in this video.

DISCLAIMER: @SeanMcDowell's study describes the historical probability of martyrdom for the apostles only verbally but doesn‚Äôt quantify it. I‚Äôve added the percentages to make the concept of probability more tangible for the viewer. However, I presented my numbers to Sean and he agreed that if he were to quantify the findings of his study, he would go for very similar figures.

title: How Women & Coca-Cola Prove the RESURRECTION
description:
Did the Resurrection really happen? ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù says the skeptic. Instead, the gospel authors must have made up the story. Admittedly, it is possible that they made it up. However, what matters is not possibility but plausibility, because a whole lot of things are possible if you just give it enough thought. For example, it is really possible that Coca-Cola‚Äôs management is trying to sell us the healthiest drink on the planet. We don‚Äôt know everything that‚Äôs going on in their minds. However, for all the facts we do know, the idea simply isn‚Äôt plausible.
Similarly, the claim that the gospel authors made up the story of the resurrection isn‚Äôt really plausible, and that‚Äôs because women feature as the key witnesses in the story. In the first century, the testimony of women was considered so unreliable and untrustworthy that they were not to testify in a Jewish court of law. This means that if you wanted to make up a story aimed at convincing people that Jesus rose from the dead the one thing you would definitely NOT do is make women your key source. Yet that‚Äôs what all four gospel authors did. Watch this video about a key topic in apologetics and Christian theology ‚Äî the resurrection of Jesus Christ ‚Äî and found out why it is plausible to think that the first Easter really did happen!

title: How the Biggest ATHEIST YouTuber Touched Me
description:
If you are into debates, there is a real danger of thinking, while you‚Äôre engaging the ‚Äúother side,‚Äù that you‚Äôre dealing with arguments only. But the truth is that behind each argument stands a real person with real struggles, real emotions, real joys. In this video, I share how one of @CosmicSkeptic's videos (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fMp0WLLrFng&t=35s) "hit" me. I realized that he has wrestled on a very personal level with an issue that‚Äôs been very important to me, too, namely, the question of whether we should give away our possessions to help more people in need. It was Alex‚Äôs sincerity in wrestling with this issue that sparked my interest in his moral philosophy. And that‚Äôs because some of the things he mentions in that video really "smack" of objective morality. So, I delved into the videos in which he carves out his ethics. I found, and unsurprisingly so, that I disagree with almost everything he lays out. However, I thought that before I move on to offer my critique, I want to put the following out there: @CosmicSkeptic‚Äôs sincerity when it comes to the issue of charity touched me personally as I could very much identify with the struggle of working through this question. And so, it is Alex‚Äôs commitment to walking the walk instead of just talking the talk that sparked my interest in his moral philosophy. So, if you‚Äôre into Christian apologetics and into debates with atheists (or with Christians, or Muslims, or others), never forget that it‚Äôs ultimately not about arguments, but about people. I hope you enjoy this video, and let me know what you think. Also, if you agree with me, please share it with someone who is dear to you, even if you disagree with their views. Thanks!

title: @CosmicSkeptic: TORN between FREE WILL, HOMOSEXUALITY & MORALITY
description:
Alex denies that free will exists. He also denies that homosexuality has anything to do with morality. In order to make that latter claim, however, he has to define the criteria which turn something into an issue related to morality. And this is where things get interesting. @CosmicSkeptic  tells us that in order for an act to fall within the moral sphere it has to be consciously chosen. But contrast that with Alex‚Äôs case against free will which culminates in the affirmation that ‚Äúyou just can‚Äôt choose what it is that you want.‚Äù In other words, @CosmicSkeptic's worldview is riddled with an outright self-contradiction. On the one hand, Alex tells us that choice is off the table, given that free will doesn‚Äôt exist. On the other hand, Alex resurrects choice in order to establish his notion of the moral sphere. Now, there is more that could be said as @CosmicSkeptic  relates free will and choice to an illusion that is beneficial to our evolution as a species. These issues make Alex‚Äôs case even more problematic. To find out why, watch this video and let me know what you think. This is a video about several key topics in Christian apologetics and debates between atheists/skeptics and Christian theists. I hope it will give you a helpful insight into the conversations that are happening around those topics in general.

title: Neuroscience Does NOT Disprove the Soul ‚Äì Interview with JP Moreland
description:
A lot of people think that neuroscience has done away with the dualist ‚Äúmyth‚Äù of the soul. Consciousness is reducible to the material brain and if not, it‚Äôs merely an ‚Äúemergent‚Äù property of the brain ‚Äì that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre being told. JP Moreland is one of the most respected philosophers of mind and his research has led him to engage with the world‚Äôs most top neuroscientists. In this interview, he will explain why neuroscience is not vested, not even in principle, with the authority to tell us whether consciousness is material or immaterial and whether the soul exists or not. Beyond that, he will point out why the dualist view (i.e. that a person consists of both a material body and an immaterial soul) is philosophically far more satisfying than physicalism (i.e. the view that everything about human beings is physical). The ‚Äúbattle‚Äù for the soul is a key topic in Christian apologetics, Christian theology, and our view about it directly impacts the way we think of human dignity, human rights, gender, and other cultural hot topics. Watch this interview and get informed about the key issues to be aware of when it comes to debating the relationship between neuroscience and dualism.

title: The Unlikely Story Behind This YouTube Channel
description: This is my first live stream in which I tell the story which led to this apologetics YouTube channel. A couple of years ago, I kicked off a Bible study for skeptics and seekers in Starbucks Beirut a couple of years ago. The idea behind this group that has become called ‚ÄúThe Infinite Cake‚Äù is to offer both an authentic community and space for everyone to ask any question they may have towards the Christian faith. At some point, one of our most faithful members, co-planted a discussion club for atheists. I joined their meetings (which took place in the same caf√© where we held our Bible study) and became very good friends with the leader. He and I decided to bring our groups together for a discussion about the relevance of religious faith and this happened in my living room. The event was a great success. Atheists, Christians, and Muslims came together to discuss their worldviews in a friendly and thoughtful manner. There was plenty of both deep conversation and laughter. We decided to do this on a regular basis and so, every other Saturday, 25-30 people would gather in my living room for what we simply called ‚Äúdiscussion nights,‚Äù which usually lasted until the early morning hours. When the leader of the atheist club left the country, he asked me whether I‚Äôd like to become the organizer/admin of his group and I happily assumed that role, and so I‚Äôm now in charge of an atheist social media profile. Ever since ‚ÄúThe Infinite Cake‚Äù and those ‚Äúdiscussion nights‚Äù in my living room got going, people encouraged me to start a YouTube channel in order to offer my arguments for the Christian faith online. This is how my YouTube channel Deflate got started. Here, I present online the things I‚Äôm talking through with my atheist friends offline in Starbucks Beirut and my living room. I‚Äôm passionate to offer high-quality apologetic video content to empower Christians, challenge skeptics, and to spark awesome discussions.

title: Skepticism Proves that God Exists: The Free-Thinking Argument with Dr. Tim Stratton
description:
Do you pride yourself on being a skeptic? Or a free-thinker? Good. But did you know that the claim that one thinks freely and rationally lends itself to a very powerful argument for God‚Äôs existence? Or to put it differently, if our ability to make rational inferences to knowledge is real, it is very unlikely that naturalism is true. Join me and my friend, Tim Stratton, for this interview in which we talk about the so-called Free-Thinking Argument Against Naturalism. Tim has spent a considerable amount of his Ph.D. developing and refining this argument and he presents it to us here in very clear and easy-to-understand terms. Many atheists claim that free will is an illusion. Yet, they also claim to be skeptics and interested in weighing evidence. However, if we don‚Äôt have free will in the libertarian sense, what good is skepticism and the considering of evidence? Against naturalism and the denial of libertarianism, skepticism and rationality itself are of no value whatsoever, and Tim will point out why this is so. This interview will touch on various topics that are paramount in Christian apologetics and the debate between atheists and Christian philosophers.

title: ATHEISM is a BELIEF according to PHILOSOPHERS.
description:
Atheists claim that atheism is merely a lack of belief. With this move, they try to rid themselves of the responsibility to back up their position with evidence and arguments. What they don‚Äôt seem to know, however, is that philosophical scholarship does not agree with their lack-of-belief definition. On the contrary, in this video, I will show that the world‚Äôs most authoritative dictionaries and encyclopedias of philosophy define atheism as an actual belief, an actual claim. Not only that but they even actively argue against the notion of atheism as a mere lack of belief. The definition of atheism is a perennial topic in apologetics and debates between atheists and Christians. So, check out this video and find out why atheism really does make a claim!

IMPORTANT EDIT: With the help of my friend Gergely Nagy (a Ph.D. student in theology), I realized that the Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy does, in fact, include the lack of belief definition, contrary to what I express in the video. I realized that when accessing the Oxford Dictionary online (I have a subscription) the Dictionary does not immediately open up its full definition. The immediate definition given is the one rendered in the video. However, the lack of belief definition is also added and I didn‚Äôt take not of that when doing my research. This means that my claim that the Oxford Dictionary of Atheism and the Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy are at odds with each other is wrong. It also means that Oxford scholarship and the two dictionaries mentioned do endorse the lack of belief definition. I sincerely apologize for this mischaracterization and thank Gergely for helping me put the record straight.

title: RELIGIOUS Beliefs: The Result of EVOLUTION!?
description:
Atheists sometimes claim that religious beliefs emerged as a result of evolution, that is because it gave our ancestors an advantage in the fight for survival. In other words, religions are all about utility for survival, but not about truth. In this video, we will examine this claim and you will learn why it fails completely on several levels.

Check out Daniel Apologetics here! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCx3wnAOBnbF2f6LJB2SXMkg

---- Content and Structure ----

0:00 Intro
0:31 Evolutionary History
1:41 The Case
2:17 Scientific Data
2:52 Natural vs Sexual Selection
5:28 A Circular Argument
7:08 Dawkins's Hypothesis
8:00 Dawkins's Failure
8:47 The Genetic Fallacy
10:03 The BIGGEST Problem
13:11 Summary

---- Summary ---

There is no scientific evidence that can justifiably be cited to locate the origin of religious belief in evolution. Instead, all the data and studies tell us refers to the beneficial effects of religious belief. This in itself renders the atheist claim an act of blind faith from the very start and it may thus be dismissed with the zero evidence with which it was asserted in the first place, as the late Christopher Hitchens advises us. Richard Dawkins offers a somewhat more sophisticated case, claiming that religious beliefs are the mere by-products of other dispositions. However, his case, too, is based on circular reasoning and therefore a logical non-starter.
But the worst is yet to follow: The claim of the atheist is completely and utterly self-undermining. That‚Äôs because underlying the argument is the rather significant implication that the thoughts generated by the human brain are aimed not at what is true but at what is helpful for survival. Sam Harris, John Gray, and many others confirm this aspect of Darwinian theory. So, if it‚Äôs true, as atheists tell us, that belief in God arose not because of its truth but because of its utility in survival, then the same thing applies to ALL our thoughts and beliefs. But now, what are we to make of the very thought that our thoughts are not aimed at truth but at survival? Is there any reason why this thought should still be taken seriously?

title: DEBUNKED: Rationality Rules Gets MATH & GOD Wrong
description:
+++ The talk about the topic starts at 2:25 (with disclaimers) and at 3:35, the real arguments get tackled. +++

William Lane Craig from @drcraigvideos recently presented an argument for God from the applicability of mathematics to the sciences. He claims that naturalism cannot explain why math works, other than by saying "it's coincidence." Stephen Woodford from @rationalityrules ationality Rules responded to Craig, arguing that there are a plethora of viable naturalistic explanations for the effectiveness of mathematics. Rationality Rules essentially argues that mathematics is a human invention which we created to come to terms with our immediate environment. And since the universe and the laws of physics are fairly consistent, it is no wonder that what we designed to come to terms with our own lives, also applies in the world of nature at large. He also claims that people like Steven Weinberg, Sabine Hossenfelder, or George Lakoof offer further examples of valid naturalistic explanations for the effectiveness of mathematics. This video is my response to Rationality Rules. What I will show is that once you examine Stephen Woodford's case, Craig's claim turns out to be true as the naturalist is indeed left with chance only to account for the effectiveness of mathematics. Who would have thought that Dr. Craig's argument for God from mathematics would pick up such momentum! Be that as it may, check our this video if you're up for exploring a very hot topic in Christian apologetics which is likely to spark further conversations between atheists, agnostics, and theists in the future. Do leave your comments, subscribe, and share the video if you like it!

Big shout-out to Spencer Smith and Dr. Hisham Gibran for helping me out big time with their feedback!

title: Christianity is responsible for Too Much EVIL!?
description:
People sometimes complain about the evil that has been committed in the name of Christianity, citing religious wars, the Crusades, abuse in religious institutions, corruption, and other misfirings. It's for this reason that the late Christopher Hitchens opined that "religion poisons everything," while Sam Harris and other atheists have expressed similar sentiments. However, when you actually look at history, things look far more complex than that. First, there's quite a bit of human suffering which has ensued from atheist ideology. The campaigns of Stalin in the Soviet Union and Mao Tse Tung in China are only two cases in point. Second, even though a lot of evil has been committed in the name of atheism, it's pretty hard to actually judge these things as evil on the assumption that atheism is true. Richard Dawkins tells us that there is no good and bad in the universe, but "only blind, pitiless indifference." But things look different if we assume Christian theism to be true. If God has imposed a moral order of objective rights and wrongs on the universe, whatever evil has been committed, be it by the church or an atheist regime, can be called out as such. In other words, while the church can be held accountable against the moral standard of Christianity, such a standard doesn't even exist in atheism. That's why a range of atheist philosophers such as Richard Rorty, Jurgen Habermas and Jacques Derrida admit that the notion of the inherent dignity of every human being, as endorsed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is a fundamentally Judeo-Christian concept, rooted in the Bible. Watch and enjoy a video about an important topic in apologetics which is often brought up in debates between skeptics and Christians. And yes, please SUBSCRIBE! üòÉ

title: DEBUNKED: Stephen on the Kalam & Free Will
description:
The Kalam Cosmological Argument is arguably one of the most discussed topics in apologetics and debates between atheists and Christian theists. William Lane Craig is its key defender and has first brought the case to the public with his book ‚ÄúThe Kalam Cosmological Argument‚Äù in 1979. @Rationality Rules, on the other hand, is a well-known YouTube channel run by atheist Stephen Woodford (it‚Äôs also the channel first recommended to me by my atheist friends). Stephen has talked about the Kalam Cosmological Argument in his own videos as well as in interactions with others (such as with Cameron Bertuzzi from @Capturing Christianity).

0:00 Intro
1:33 Stephen's Case
2:21 Stephen's Definitions
2:32 Stephens' Confusion About Cause and Determinism
6:18 Causation and Libertarian Free Will
7:32 Defining Free Will
9:30 The Core Claim
11:28 Debunking Stephen
13:20 Cause ‚â† Determinism!
14:48 Free Will Is Not Uncaused!
16:09 Conclusion

Recently, Stephen published a video under the title ‚ÄúThe Great Cost of the Kalam‚Äù in which he claims that both the Kalam Cosmological Argument and libertarian free will cannot be affirmed consistently at one at the same time. The concept of free will, according to @Rationality Rules, does not allow to state the first premise of the Kalam Cosmological Argument without perpetuating a self-contradiction. And yet, according to @Rationality Rules, the majority of theologians, Christian philosophers, and apologists such as William Lane Craig or Frank Turek who affirm the Kalam Cosmological Argument also affirm libertarian free will. Stephen Woodford from @Rationality Rules does not hold to libertarian free will (or libertarianism), but he is a determinist instead. However, this is immaterial to the case he has offered since it‚Äôs not about whether determinism or libertarian free will are true, but rather whether libertarian free will AND the Kalam Cosmological Argument can be true at one and the same time. Stephen from @Rationality Rules answers this question in the negative. However, in his video, he openly asks for a response from those who disagree with his claim about the incompatibility of the Kalam and libertarian free will, and this video is a reply to that invitation.

My video will show is that @Rationality Rules‚Äô case is based on a fundamental confusion between the concept of cause and the concept of causal determinism. The latter is but a particular theory of causation, that is, a theory of how causes work out in reality, so to speak. Rationality Rules, however, claims that the term ‚Äúcause‚Äù and the term ‚Äúcausal determinism‚Äù refer to one and the same thing. He further holds that on libertarianism, acts of free will are essentially uncaused, which is another misunderstanding. Libertarians do not claim that acts of free will are uncaused, all they claim is that they are not determined. Yet, @Rationality Rules seems to believe that ‚Äúnot having a cause‚Äù is the same as ‚Äúnot being determined.‚Äù It‚Äôs based on these misconceptions that Stephen builds his case against the compatibility of the Kalam Cosmological Argument and libertarian free will. In my response, I attempt to clear up @Rationality Rules‚Äô confusion and show that there is no problem whatsoever with affirming both the Kalam Cosmological Argument and libertarian free will.

I‚Äôm open to pushback from Stephen and hope that this will spark fruitful conversations. Enjoy!

The link to @Rationality Rules‚Äô video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qm_6eB5bcos&t=3s

title: Did You Know that Evil DISPROVES Atheism?
description:
Oftentimes, you‚Äôll hear atheists claim that if God existed, there would certainly be no evils such as massacres, wars, child abuse, cancer, and what have you. Now, the problem of evil is a serious and complex one, and I will certainly not be able to cover all its aspects in one single video. But the one thing you will learn in this video is why it is the height of inconsistency for an atheist to even talk about the problem of evil. That‚Äôs because, on the assumption of atheism, the notion that there is a dichotomy between good and evil is as delusional as the notion that green unicorns and pink dragons race against each other around planet earth. Watch this episode to find out why any coherent discourse about the problem of evil has to assume the existence of God. Enjoy, comment, subscribe, and share!

title: Why Evolution Does NOT Support Atheism
description:
Many people think that because evolution is a fact, God does not exist and atheism wins. But if you read Darwin's The Origin of Species, you'll find that Darwin himself never thought so. And yet, Richard Dawkins continues to preach that "Darwin has made it possible to be an intellectually fulfilled atheist." Check out this episode to find out why evolution, even if it was true, would do nothing to disprove the existence of God. Enjoy!
